Sindikat predlaga dodatna cepljenja za policiste
04 Nov 2019, 14:49 by STA

Sindikat policistov Slovenije predlaga, naj se policiste, ki delajo z nezakonitimi migranti, dodatno preventivno cepi. Vojakom, ki sodelujejo v mešanih patruljah, so na voljo nekatera cepljenja, ki policistom niso, so opozorili v sindikatu. Pozvali so tudi k določitvi protokola za ravnanje policista ob sumu na nalezljivo bolezen.



Fotografija je simbolična. Foto: Leo Caharija

LJUBLJANA > Za posamezne skupine policistov je glede na njihovo delo predvidena shema cepljenja, so pojasnili v sporočilu za javnost. Največ cepljenj je predvidenih za policiste, ki jih napotijo na delo v tujino. Policisti, ki so odšli v Severno Makedonijo, so cepljenji proti davici, tetanusu, oslovskemu kašlju, mumpsu, rdečkam, hepatitisu A in B ter tifusu. Preverili so tudi cepljenje proti ošpicam, ki so ga po potrebi tudi izvedli.
Dodatna cepljenja so na voljo tudi pripadnikom posebne policijske enote, policistom v centru za tujce in policistom, ki jih individualno napotijo v tujino. Preostali policisti pa so upravičeni do cepljenja proti klopnemu meningoencefalitisu in proti gripi.
"Do ostalih cepljenj pa niso upravičeni, čeprav se srečujejo in imajo stike z migranti z istih območij, kot na primer policisti, ki so napoteni v Severno Makedonijo," so poudarili v sindikatu.
Ob tem so v sindikatu opozorili tudi na neenakost v primerjavi z vojaki, ki sodelujejo v mešanih patruljah. Vojaki so namreč cepljeni proti hepatitisu A in B, tifusu, tetanusu, davici, ošpicam in oslovskemu kašlju. Poudarili so tudi, da imajo po njihovih informacijah vojaki, ki niso cepljeni, pravico, da odklonijo napotitev na opravljanje nalog povezanih z migranti in ne izvajajo postopkov z migranti.
Zato so v sindikatu na ministrstvo za notranje zadeve in policijo naslovili pobudo, naj se v okviru varstva pred boleznimi izpostavi bolezni, s katerimi se lahko okužijo pri opravljanju dela z nezakonitimi migranti in se zagotovi cepljenje na način, kot velja za vojake in policiste, ki jih napotijo v tujino.
Prav tako si v Sindikatu policistov Slovenije želijo protokol za ravnanje v primeru suma na okužbo z nalezljivo boleznijo. Želijo si, da je v protokolu opredeljeno tudi, "da se vsaj v prvi fazi domnevne okužbe odsvetuje socialne in druge stike osebe z okolico, torej tudi z družino in sodelavci, kot to predlaga zdravstvena stroka".
text:
The union proposes additional vaccinations for police officers
04 Nov 2019, 14:49 by STA

The Union of Police Officers of Slovenia proposes that the police officers working with illegal migrants should be further prevented. There are some vaccinations available to soldiers participating in mixed patrols that are not available to police officers, the union warned. They also called for the establishment of a protocol for policing suspected infectious diseases.



Photography is symbolic. Photo by Leo Cahari

LJUBLJANA> A vaccination scheme is planned for individual groups of police officers, according to a press release. Most vaccinations are planned for police officers who are seconded to work abroad. Police officers who went to Northern Macedonia are vaccinated against diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis, mumps, rubella, hepatitis A and B, and typhoid. They also checked for measles vaccination, which was also performed as needed.
Additional vaccinations are also available to members of the special police unit, police officers at the Aliens Center and police officers who are seconded individually. However, the remaining police officers are entitled to vaccination against tick-borne meningoencephalitis and influenza.
"However, they are not entitled to other vaccinations, although they do encounter and have contacts with migrants from the same areas, such as police officers posted to Northern Macedonia," the union stressed.
The union also warned of inequality compared to soldiers participating in mixed patrols. The soldiers are vaccinated against hepatitis A and B, typhoid, tetanus, diphtheria, measles and pertussis. They also stressed that, according to their information, non-vaccinated soldiers have the right to refuse a referral to perform migrant-related tasks and not carry out procedures with migrants.
As a result, the union has submitted an initiative to the Ministry of the Interior and the police to expose, within the framework of disease protection, diseases that can be contaminated when dealing with illegal migrants and to provide vaccination in the way that applies to soldiers and police officers who they are sent abroad.
The Slovenian Police Union also wants a protocol for dealing with suspected infectious disease. They want the protocol to also stipulate that "at least in the first phase of the alleged infection, the social and other contacts of the person with their surroundings, ie with family and colleagues, as suggested by the medical profession" are advised.
